title: What is your PhD thesis in one sentence? - Quora

response.answer_text: This very question had been put to me by a diverse range of people during my PhD and my answer always depended upon the person who asked them. From the top of my head, here are a number of answers which I had given to a range of interesting people: Random stranger at the bus-stop/pub/subway/restaurant etc.): So basically…I am researching to see if e-cigarettes cause any harm or not…and I am doing this without using any animals…so just…you know…using human cells from the lungs…it is really cool! (Ends the conversation by giving them my personal opinion)School kid (interested in science, especially biology): Yeah so…I am looking into the possible effects of e-cigarettes, you know these products, don’t you? (waits for a response)…so I am basically trying to research what happens when I deliver e-cigarette vapours over a layer of human cells derived from the lung…what do you think might happen? (waits to hear their answer and continues to stimulate more interest)Rough school kid (not interested in science, me trying to stimulate an interest): Well, you know these e-cigarettes…the vaping stuff that everyone are using right? I am trying to find out if they are harmful to our lungs or not. And so far, my research has shown that they might not be that good…you know why? (Waits for a response from the kid and then continues to give moreinsight)Fellow PhD student (biologist): I’m investigating the cytotoxicity of e-cigarette aerosols using an in-vitro, co-culture model of differentiated human bronchial epithelium with underlying pulmonary fibroblasts. (Goes into an in-depth explanation of the experimental designs and the research questions being addressed)Fellow PhD student (non-biologist): I’m assessing the toxicity of e-cigarette vapours using relevant cell types from the human lungs. (The person’s response then steers the conversation in different directions)University Professors (biologist): I am investigating the mechanisms of cell death and pro-inflammatory mediators production, chiefly IL-6 and IL-8, by human bronchial epithelial cells and pulmonary fibroblasts in response to different doses of e-cigarette aerosols delivered via a bespoke breathing system. (Goes on to ask for the Professor’s insight on my experimental design and possible avenues to further explore)University Professors (non-biologist): Same answer as for ‘Fellow PhD student (non-biologist)’ (Ends with an interesting fact about e-cigarettes and how my research might help the scientific community!)Engineers (with an interest in biology): I am investigating the effects of e-cigarette vapour on the human lung cells and in order to deliver the e-cigarette vapour in a physiologically relevant fashion, I have constructed a automated ‘aerosol delivery system’ in-house. (Goes on to ask for the Engineers’s feedback on my system design and ways to simplify/improvise the design further. Note that more emphasis was placed on the engineering aspect and not the biological)Engineers (with no interest in biology): I am focused on exploring the toxicity profiles of different e-cigarettes and in this pursuit, to deliver e-cigarette aerosols in a controlled fashion to the cells, I have built a prototype using micro-controllers that would effectively ‘puff’ the e-cigarettes in a regulated manner. Would you like to have a look? (Again, Note that more emphasis was placed on the engineering aspect and not the biological)As you would have noticed, I change my answers considerably depending upon the level of scientific knowledge the questioner might possess (a random assessment). In fact, I strongly believe that one skill every PhD student should develop over the course of their study is this: the ability to explain their thesis in a number of different ways to both specialists as well as non-specialists, focusing only on the relevant areas of their research depending upon the person they are talking to. Trust me, this skill is a gem!  Also, this is obviously not to say that a lay man is less-intellectual than a scientist. In deed, some of the most brilliant counter-questions/arguments I have ever received and that I ever struggled to answer were from the general audience. I am sure it is true of many other scientists as well. The goal of the answer is to demonstrate the importance of developing science communication skills and how this skill can significantly improve you as a scientist, besides giving you an upper edge during job interviews, workshops, conferences and general presentations. P.S: If you would like to know my answer to any other personalities other than that listed above, feel free to add them in the comments. I would be delighted to attempt to answer them. The tougher, the better! Pranav

In the mid-20th century, when scientists said “public understanding of science,” what they meant was “public appreciation of the benefits that science provides to society.”  Lewenstein, Bruce V. (1987). 'Public Understanding of Science' in America, 1945-1965. (Ph.D. dissertation), University of Pennsylvania, Abstract:The 20 years after World War II (1945-1965) saw the rise of a formal, institutional concern with popular science, which came to be known as the "problem" of "public understanding of science." This dissertation traces the rise of that concern, and the reaction to it by four groups: commercial publishers, scientific societies, science writers, and government agencies. Although each group had its own reasons for responding, they came to a consensus: the term "public understanding of science" meant "public appreciation of and support for the benefits that science provides to society." The consensus developed because the groups shared common values, especially a moral commitment to the value of science in the modern world and a belief in the congruence of science with democracy. The thesis begins by examining two magazines created in the late 1940s, the short-lived Science Illustrated and the new Scientific American, to show that economic constraints dictated the response of commercial publishers to the public understanding of science problem. Next, a discussion of the American Association for the Advancement of Science's renewed commitment to public understanding of science in the early 1950s shows the institutional revitalization that popular science provided to scientific societies. Public understanding of science also provided a route to professionalization for science writers during the 1950s (especially through the National Association of Science Writers and its offshoot. the Council for the Advancement of Science Writing). At government agencies such as the Atomic Energy Commission, the National Science Foundation, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, "public education" proved an effective institutional rationale for public information activities. Finally, despite its institutional focus, the thesis acknowledges the special role of foundation executive Warren Weaver (1894-1978) in shaping public understanding of science programs during the postwar period. The thesis is based on extensive archival research, contemporary published materials, and interviews with participants. It is part of an emerging literature that treats popular science as an element of the history and sociology of science, rather than as a branch of journalism.

The way we learn a second language is not* entirely unrelated to the way we learn other stuff. One of the theoretical questions behind how we learn language is how much of the learning process is language specific, and therefore (perhaps) innate. Statistical learning (SL) is a specific sub-type of learning—it is the way we extract information from structured input, or on simple terms, how we learn predictability, how we learn that lightning follows thunder. It has been proposed that statistical learning, together with communicative biases from information theory and the structure of the linguistic input we get, may be sufficient to explain language learning (contra to what has been proposed by generative theories of language acquisition), in which case we don't need to posit any innate linguistic knowledge (Chomsky's language acquisition device). However this is a field in its infancy. We know that individual differences in all sorts of SL tasks are somewhat related to all sorts of language processing and acquisition measures, but that is obviously quite a long way from what we are actually asking. In my PhD, I'm trying to better understand how linguistic stimuli effect SL processes, and exactly how SL performance is related to second language learning (mainly because first language acquisition is really difficult to study, because it's done by babies and little kids, who make problematic subjects, especially if you want to look at their brains.) *Hopefully… I'm still only part way through my PhD.  I know this isn't what was asked, but here's my master's thesis, because at least this is work that has actually been finished and published… Modern Hebrew has Semitic structure, just like everyone has always learned it does. There is an ongoing debate as to whether, from a cognitive perspective, Hebrew really has a root and template structure, or whether all (Modern) Hebrew words are derived from other words, and the root morpheme doesn't actually exist as an abstract morpheme. There's a whole bunch of evidence that when we (i.e. native readers of Hebrew) read words in Hebrew, there are certain phenomena, namely priming effects, that are dependent specifically on the root consonants, and not on templatic consonants or on the semantics of the root morpheme. This has been taken as evidence for the “cognitive reality” of the root. However some linguists have claimed that these priming effects are artefacts of frequency and processing, and do not reflect the underlying cognitive system. This is backed up by the fact that a whole family of processes involving denominal verbs cannot be explained with reference to the root, and must be based on full word-forms. There are also a whole load of theoretical and ideological reasons these people don't want to allow for abstract morphemes. I showed that the priming effects with roots do not occur with denominal verbs, and they are only primed by the full verbal word-form from which they are derived. Given our model of the mental lexicon, this both explains why the denominal phenomena are word-based, and also proves that the original priming phenomena must be a reflection of the underlying cognitive structure of the language, and cannot be a frequency or processing artefact.

We don’t have to teach anyone about store buffers. If you’re a programmer and you’ve never heard about store buffers, you should be thankful to me and the giants whose shoulders I’m standing on. It’s because of us that you never heard about them and never have to hear about them in your life. Now you’re probably thinking “what are store buffers and why should I care that I don’t have to know about them? I’ve never come in contact with store buffers in my whole life.” But if you’re thinking that, you’re very wrong. You’re probably reading this on a device that uses store buffers, namely if you’re using an Intel or AMD processor (and probably ARM processors also have store buffers, but I wouldn’t know). What they are? Little to-do-lists. You see, processors are procrastinators of the worst sort (and I’m sure I’ve said this before). When they execute a statement that is supposed to change the value of some variables, they think “ugh… the way to the shared memory is too long… and then I’ll have to stand in the queue and wait until there’s a free seat in the memory bus…” So they simply don’t change the value of the variable. They just add an item at the end of their to-do-list: “□◻ change variable x to value 5” or something like that. And eventually, when “the moment is right”, when they’re “in the mood”, the processor gets around to actually changing the variable. Often that is hundreds of instructions later. As you can probably imagine, this has very funny effects on your program, at least if you have multiple threads. The classical example is a software lock, where the threads tell each other that they want to enter the critical section, but then only enter the critical section if the other thread doesn’t want to do that too: int enterCrit1 = 0, enterCrit2 = 0; int z = 0;  void Thread1() { 	enterCrit1 = 1; // announce intent to enter critical section 	if (enterCrit2 == 0) { 		// if Thread 2 didn't also announce intent, enter critical section 		z++;  	} }  void Thread2() { 	enterCrit2 = 1; 	if (enterCrit1 == 0) { // critical section 		z++; 	} } Now you’d expect that one of the threads will make the first step, change the variable, and thus the other thread will see the new value of 1 and not enter the critical section. But on an Intel machine, the processor will “eventually get around to it” and the variables will not be changed for a while, thus both threads can (and likely will) enter the critical section. So why have you never heard about this? I must be bullshitting you, right? Nope. You can read all about it in the Intel® 64 and IA-32 architectures software developer's manual volume 3A: System programming guide, part 1. The reason why you never heard about it is simple: if you translated the above program to C, the program would have undefined semantics (because of, you know, store buffers). To get defined semantics you have to add some program annotations, using which the program can be compiled correctly. Races — i.e., memory accesses of different threads to the same variable that can occur “concurrently” (and one is changing the value) — need to be annotated somehow. In C/C++, you have to mark the variables as atomic, in Java you have to annotate the variables as volatile. Now here’s the prize question: does the variable z need to be annotated as well? In the naive computational model (without store buffers) the answer is no, because as we discussed above only one of the threads can enter the critical section and access z. But in the real hardware (with store buffers), the answer would at first be yes, because both threads can put their assignments on the to-do-list and enter the critical section, thus concurrently accessing z. The central point of what I show* in my thesis is that you don’t have to look at the computational model with store buffers at all. So you can simply look at all of the races in the naive model — where z is not being accessed by multiple threads — and annotate only the races in that model. That is enough for the compiler to make sure that your program is not messed up by the store buffers (by adding slow synchronization instructions just at the right places) and thus even when running on the real hardware, you will never have a race on z. To summarize, you don’t need to know what store buffers do or even that they exist. Just look at your program the way you always have, annotate the races you find, and your program will run on Intel and AMD processors as if they didn’t have the store buffers that you don’t even know exist. (*) I’m not the first one to show such a result — Ernie Cohen and Norbert Schirmer were —, but I extend their result on several fronts, e.g., to architectures with half-word accesses, devices, operating system code that runs untrusted compiled user code (imagine it’s compiled from C code where the annotations are wrong or don’t exist), inter processor interrupts, etc. Lots of stuff that really rocks the boat :)

I ran huge supercomputer simulations of the Universe’s evolution from the Big Bang until today, costing millions of taxpayer dollars, just to explain a bunch of faint wiggles of light that wasn’t there. Funny enough, my thesis was quite important at the time. It was a finalist for the Trumpler Prize for best astronomy PhD thesis. I lost out to some guy named Adam Riess whose thesis discovered dark energy or some such thing. I’m still sore about that, I mean Adam Riess… pfftt… what’s that guy ever done*? To elaborate a bit more on my PhD thesis: The space in between galaxies actually contains far more matter than the galaxies themselves, and in fact traces out a vast network of filaments and sheets known as the Cosmic Web.  My thesis was on numerical simulations that explained the origin of the so-called Lyman-alpha forest - Wikipedia, which is absorption (“missing light”) in the light from background galaxies or quasars owing to intervening matter that traces out the Cosmic Web. My simulations were the first to show how the complicated pattern of absorption features excellently matches the expectations from numerical simulations of the Cosmic Web across most of cosmic time.  My thesis was in 1998. Today, these faint wiggles of the Lyman alpha forest represent one of the pillars of cosmology used to constrain the nature of dark matter and dark energy. * Adam, of course, later won the Nobel Prize for the work he did for his PhD thesis :)

Designing rapid techniques for the synthesis of materials for water purification and solid state lighting.. basically white light LED’s that the whole world’s going nuts over (for good reason). Actual thesis title: Solution based synthesis of wide bandgap semiconductor nanomaterials (Not so fancy now, is it! Pfft.. lame ass title, I know!) My whole thesis is available for anyone who is interested! On a side note: Water purification and solid state lighting are just two of the several applications that I focused on. The materials we prepared can be used in medicine, in solar cells, archaeology, energy storage, electronics, optoelectronics, and in a whole lot of fascinating applications. Essentially, my work involved the use of novel, new, solution based techniques for the rapid synthesis of nanocrystalline ceramic materials that can be used as efficient photocatalysts and as phosphors in solid state lighting. The techniques I’d proposed in my thesis can reduce the manufacturing costs of these LED’s significantly as well as improve the the quality of groundwater when applied to industrial wastewater treatment plants. We actually did end up collaborating with one such industrial wastewater treatment company to commercialize some of our materials. I focused specifically on a category of metal oxides called spinels because of their specific and interesting crystal structure and their superior thermo-chemical stabilities. I investigated the effects rapid synthesis and post synthesis processing techniques on the crystal structure and how specific defects could be induced in it. More specifically, I used to do a comprehensive structure-property correlation study on my materials and tried to figure out how synthesis plays a role on cationic inversion in the lattice and how this inversion affected their optical properties.

How to deal with a small business without crushing them. My dissertation dealt with how small disadvantaged businesses survive and thrive in a large supply chain. The genesis of the problem statement was that I noted that there were many qualitative case studies and phenomenological studies on how small disadvantaged businesses survived, grew, and developed over time. However, I was not able to find any quantitative studies on the same subject. One particular case study (dissertation) gave me some very good ideas as to how to approach the problem and study. I also found an article and read a presentation to Congress by the Secretary of Commerce where it was stated that competition of the future would not really be company to company, but instead could be characterized by being supply chain to supply chain, and small businesses were going to be key because of some strategic and tactical advantages over large, cumbersome organizations. Noting the footnotes, the Small Business Administration has piles of data just laying around for someone to pick it up and do something with it (like a formal study). So, my approach was to use archival data in a quasi-experimental study. It turned out to be kind of fun, and in the end, my committee seemed to appreciate that there is a lot of depth yet to be plumbed. Small disadvantaged businesses carry that label for a reason. I was just trying to figure out to what extent large companies can mentor the smaller business and help to assure their success.

If you know how to simulate the motion of atoms of a solid, you can figure out some really cool stuff about the line defects in crystals.  Line defects a.k.a. dislocations, are a special type of imperfections in the otherwise ordered structure of a crystal. They are associated with several important properties of materials, the most glaring of them being their role in the plastic deformation of solids.[1] In addition, they are technologically important in the context of semiconductors, superconductors, magnetism of solids, crystal growth, etc. With the advances in computer technologies in the domains of algorithms, software and hardware, it has become possible to simulate the dynamics of millions of atoms of a solid. By tracking the trajectories of a large number of individual atoms, it is possible to examine the time evolution of the structure of the whole sample. This technique is known as molecular dynamics simulation. In my thesis, I have employed such computer simulations to investigate the structure and dynamics of crystal dislocations. There are four distinct findings that emerged out of my work: Dislocations tend to move faster when they are in close proximity of a free surface.[2]If a moving dislocation suddenly encounters an obstacle, it can start vibrating like the plucked string of a guitar.[3]If a dislocation moves past a small void in the crystal, its shape alters due to a special kind of motion called “climb”.[4]At ultra-small scale of length, the motion of a dislocation is not smooth but jerky.[5]I absolutely loved my PhD days. Footnotes[1] Amlan Dutta's answer to Why is dislocation very important in metal and alloys?[2] Lattice Resistance to Dislocation Motion at the Nanoscale[3] Inertial oscillations of a pinned dislocation[4] The mechanism of climb in dislocation–nanovoid interaction[5] Quasistatic stick-slip of a dislocation core and the Frenkel-Kontorova chain

“ My PhD thesis primarily focuses on the growth aspects of single crystal wide band gap semiconductors such as gallium nitride on alumina substrates for various optical and electronic applications. ” I have tried my best to understand how the thermodynamic and kinetic parameters influence the purity, polarity, crystalline and surface quality of GaN epitaxial layers. The processing technique used was metal organic chemical vapor deposition and is well known for its ability in producing high quality semiconductor layers. GaN has wurtzite structure (hexagonal symmetry). The common crystallographic growth direction is [0001] or we can say that the growth is favorable along the c-direction in terms of hexagonal crystallography. Interestingly, GaN in this direction terminates either with Ga atoms or N atoms. The former case is commonly called as Ga-face/Ga-polar GaN, while the later one is called as N-face/N-polar GaN as depicted in the following figure. Consequently, the GaN crystal has an inbuilt spontaneous polarization and is useful especially in fabricating the high electron mobility transistors for various applications.  The GaN based technology that exists today is mostly based on Ga-polar GaN. The reason why only Ga-polar GaN is that it is kinetically more favorable than N-polar GaN. While N-polar GaN is suggested to have the ability to enhance the current GaN based technology further. However, the growth of N-polar GaN is not kinetically favorable and the films grown are very rough and poor in crystalline quality. My PhD thesis deals with the growth of N-polar GaN. I was able to develop the device quality N-polar GaN layers on alumina substrates by careful optimization of thermodynamical and kinetic parameters involved.

Your dissertation is important for the prerequisites for a Ph.D. The research, hypothesis, experimentation, et al. likewise contribute. One doesn't endeavor to catch everything in one's dissertation. The dissertation is a specialized work used to record and put forward confirmation of one's proposition. It is proposed for a specialized crowd, and it must be clear and complete, however not really thoroughly far-reaching. Likewise note - trial information, whenever utilized, isn't the confirmation - it is proof. The verification is introduced as examination and basic introduction. When in doubt, each announcement in your dissertation must be regular information, upheld by reference to specialized writing, or, in all likelihood unique outcomes demonstrated by the applicant (you). Every one of those statements should straightforwardly identify with the confirmation of the proposal or probably they are not required. The dissertation isn't the theory. One's theory is a case - speculation. The dissertation depicts, in detail, how one demonstrates the speculation (or, infrequently, discredits the case and shows other significant outcomes). How about we return to the possibility of the theory itself. It is a theory, a guess, a hypothesis. The dissertation is a formal, adapted archive used to contend your proposition. The postulation must be critical, unique (nobody has yet exhibited it to be valid), and it must expand the condition of logical information. The principal thing you have to do is to concocted close to three sentences that express your proposition. Your board of trustees must concur that your statements structure a substantial postulation explanation. You too should be content with the announcement - it ought to be what you will tell anybody on the off chance that they ask you what your proposal is (barely any individuals will need to hear an hour introduction as a reaction). When you have an announcement of the proposition, you can start to build up the dissertation. The theoretical, for example, ought to be a one-page depiction of your postulation and how you present its evidence. The theoretical ought, to sum up the consequences of the postulation and should pressure the commitments to science made along these lines. Maybe the most ideal approach to see how a theoretical should look is to inspect the modified works of a few dozen dissertations that have just been acknowledged. Our college library has an assortment of them. This is a decent way to deal with perceive how a whole dissertation is organized and introduced. MIT press has distributed the ACM doctoral dissertation grant arrangement for longer than 10 years, so you may discover a portion of those to be genuine guides to peruse - they ought to be in any enormous specialized library. The dissertation itself ought to be organized into 4 to 6 sections. Coming up next is one usually utilized structure: Presentation. Spread a prologue to the fundamental phrasing, offer references to proper foundation work, quickly talk about related work that has just secured parts of the issue. Unique model. Examine a theoretical model of what you are attempting to demonstrate. This section ought not to talk about a particular execution (see beneath) Approval of model/confirmation of hypotheses. This is a section indicating proof of the model. This could be a lot of confirmations, or a conversation of development and approval of a model or recreation to be utilized in get-together supporting information. Estimations/information. This would be an introduction of different information gathered from genuine use, from reproductions, or from different sources. The introduction would incorporate examination to show uphold for the hidden postulation. collect your Diplomas paper in here-https://zakazat-kursovuyu.ru/ Extra outcomes. In some work, there might be optional affirmation studies, or the reality of the situation might prove that extra significant outcomes are gathered en route to the confirmation of the focal postulation. These would be introduced here. Ends and future work. This is the place the outcomes are largely integrated and introduced. Impediments, limitations, and extraordinary cases ought to be obviously expressed here alongside the outcomes. Some unmistakable augmentations to future work may likewise be depicted. How about we take a gander at these in somewhat more detail Section I, Introduction. Here, you ought to plainly express the postulation and its significance. This is likewise where you give meanings of terms and different ideas utilized elsewhere. There is no compelling reason to compose 80 pages of foundation on your point here. Rather, you can cover nearly everything by saying: "The phrasing utilized in this work coordinates the definitions given in [citation, citation] except if noted something else." Then, refer to some fitting works that give the definitions you need. The advancement of science is that we learn and utilize crafted by others (with proper credit). Expect you have an in fact educated readership acquainted with (or ready to discover) normal references. Try not to reference mainstream writing or WWW locales on the off chance that you can support it (this involves style more than all else - you need to reference articles in refereed meetings and diaries, if conceivable, or in different postulations).

A short version: I spied on people (with their permission) by having them wear cameras and learned some important properties of real world autobiographical memory (as opposed to lab based "artificial" memories). A longer more accurate version: In my thesis, I first describe some dynamical properties of real-world context (which is an important construct in mathematical and verbal theories of memory) captured by individuals wearing lifelogging devices [1], then explore ways in which these real-world contexts (as opposed to lab contexts) influence autobiographical memory and finally describe the neural correlates of real-world context and memory. References* 1. Sreekumar, V., Dennis, S., Doxas, I., Zhuang, Y., & Belkin, M. (2014). The geometry and dynamics of lifelogs: Discovering the organizational principles of human experience. PloS one, 9(5), e97166. Publisher’s version (Open Access) 2. Nielson, D. M., Smith, T. A., Sreekumar, V., Dennis, S., & Sederberg, P. B. (2015). Human hippocampus represents space and time during retrieval of real-world memories. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 112(35), 11078-11083. Publisher’s version 3. Sreekumar, V., Dennis, S., & Doxas, I. (2017). The episodic nature of experience: A dynamical systems analysis. Cognitive Science, 41(5), 1377-1393. doi: 10.1111/cogs.12399 Publisher’s version 4. Dennis S., Yim, H., Sreekumar, V., Evans, N. J., Garrett, P., & Sederberg, P. (2017). A hierarchical Bayesian model of “memory for when” based on experience sampling data. In G. Gunzelmann, A. Howes, T. Tenbrink, & E. Davelaar (Eds.), Proceedings of the 39th Annual Conference Cognitive Science Society. London, UK: Cognitive Science Society. *Edited to update reference list. See Vishnu Sreekumar, Ph.D. for more details.

Thesis given to name a title or tell the whole story it in one sentence is always a mind-boggling thing. But, when you start to draft the thesis, pen down the research points that you doing first. For eg. I’ve done my thesis topic in philosophy. I just want to see the effect of money - what alters the millennials draw through. The topic I chose is classified and focused on both positives and negatives of a coin, that why money is so crucially plotted into younger generations' minds. If I’d to summarise the whole thesis in on sentence i.e.., Money is uncannily similar to Jelly. I made research under so many things in subplots as, money as emotion, why money takes guards in people's mindset for taking a life in proper standards, etc… As you research and finalize the thesis, show the impact of whatever line you mend to write. NOTE: BE ALWAYS PRACTICAL AND LOGICAL IN WRITING.

“Three Things You Can Do With Twitter Data — You’ll Never Believe #2!” My advisor told me that after I finish writing my third paper I can staple my three projects together and call it a thesis. They are pretty unrelated to each other, but they all have to do with Twitter data, in some form or another. The actual working title of my thesis is “Advantages and Limitations of Social Recommendation Systems,” and project #2 was on using Twitter data to deanonymize people’s web browsing histories.

In one sentence, it goes as ‘How to regenerate the mammalian heart?’ Our heart is one of the most amazing organs in our body and as you know in simple words, it helps pump blood throughout the body. One of the major causes of deaths worldwide is via cardiovascular or heart diseases and it is potentially because of the inability of the heart to regrow itself, due to excessive loss of its cells known as the cardiomyocytes. Interesting, because the cardiomyocytes can no longer proliferate like the liver cells or skin cells, we do not have heart cancer! (Wow!) But it also means a major loss of these cells would render the organ non-functional and eventual death. We are partly aware of the different mechanisms that leads to the development of a functional heart in mammals. My focus lies in trying to understand if we can revert one of these mechanisms in adult heart, therby restoring its ability to proliferate again and thus prevent fatality owing to cardiovascular diseases.

Boy frogs croak: since girls Find local croaks much cuter, New bogs make new frogs!  Explanation: for a long time biologists have debated how new species arise. Could newly-evolved species avoid cross-breeding while living in the same area? If not, they would merge or go extinct whenever they met. My project involved building computer simulations of an Australian frog, looking at how mating preferences and signals (croaking) would evolve and affect speciation. It turns out that how preferences and signals evolve depends on how the frogs are arranged in their environment. The frogs would usually evolve to prefer whatever signal was most common nearby, and to signal whatever was preferred nearby. This positive feedback loop could help them evolve to avoid mating with other frog populations. Patchy habitats (like bogs) were especially good for making new species in this way. The details are tedious. But it’s fun to think about analogous processes in human cultural evolution.

To trust or not to trust. My thesis revolved around understanding the semantics of human communication to infer trust between them. One of the best application of such contribution is to estimate team performance. My datasets were primarily emails and chats. My work was supported by funding from HP Labs, NSA, and US Army Research. My PhD thesis can be found here. Understanding Human Communication to Estimate Trust, Hierarchy, and Performance. Some relevant papers in this direction are: 1. Computing Team Process Measures From the Structure and Content of Broadcast Collaborative Communications (http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7883917/) 2. Güven: Estimating Trust from Communications (Güven: estimating trust from communications) 3. Muon: Designing Multiagent Communication Protocols from Interaction scenarios (Muon: designing multiagent communication protocols from interaction scenarios) 4. Monitoring Commitments in People-Driven Service Engagements (http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6649691/)

“The Application of Expert Systems Techniques in the Design of Durable Concrete” A real page-turner! Written using Lotus Manuscript with images, graphs etc printed separately and collated into the draft. I called the associated Expert System “Durex” but was required to rename it by my Prof. It also featured a Lotus-123 spreadsheet for mix design with formulae which were based on the interpolation between points on the published design graphs. The help-system I wrote for it was my first crack at HTML and even had an interactive map of UK soil types. I seem to recall submitting it to the printer just after the deadline but crying until they took pity on me. Never let it be said that Brummie Book Binders have no heart.  I ended up with ‘major revisions’ because I spent too much time trying to create a commercial system rather than advancing the science of concrete mixology and who could blame me?

Dopamine and acetylcholine drugs can literally change the speed of your internal clocks, and my computational model of the relevant basal ganglia circuit demonstrates how.  I just added the pdf to my ResearchGate profile: A neural network model of reinforcement-driven acquisition and performance of timed action switching in corticostriatal circuits

Some people are born mad, some achieve madness, and some have madness thrust upon them by the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. More serious answer: The arguments in contemporary debates about whether something should be a mental illness, and what the specific criteria should be, consist of recirculated rhetorical forms that have developed over the last two millennia, driven as much by cultural and linguistic pressures as scientific ones, and this recirculation is not cosmetic but rather deeply substantive.

Extract microstructural information in brain using MRI in a single scan along with T1 and T2. Microstructure is the structure and packing of different kinds of cells at the subvoxel level. Extracting such information without actually obtaining MR images at cellular resolution is the crux of the project. This will enable us to study stroke, demyelination diseases and anything that causes structural changes in the brain which most diseases do. This is also useful in studying diffusion tractography, the cool images of axons in white matter.  Photo: Siemens healthcare

I identified ways of making an inert polymer into a spongy biologically-active matrix for cells, specifically vascular endothelial cells. We also used clever engineering to make the same polymer into a drug delivery vehicle that exhibited some therapeutic effect in a mouse model of ocular vascular disease. belair dg - PubMed - NCBI

Your abstract is a very good summary of your PhD thesis. And usually it consists of four or five paragraphs, depending on the style adopted by different institutions. However a summary of your thesis can be a little more detailed to contain: Paragraph1- An introduction to your topic showing previous concern ,as a problem or issue of concern, why the need to study it and gap in studies which your work has filled. It should introduce the main objective Paragraph 2: This should present the frame work of your work, theoretical framework, methodology used in the research towards in selecting materials, respondents or participants and study location or laboratory etc, towards achieving the specific objectives of the study and methods of analysis adopted, with justifications. Paragraph 3: This should provide key findings from the field or laboratory work engaged in paragraph 2. It should be present along each specific objective or research questions/ hypothesis. It should be used to answer the research questions and objectives. The content should be presented in logical sequence that will fuse into the previous paragraphs Paragraph 4 and 5 will present the summary and conclusion of the findings and then the recommendation flowing from there. It may also include suggestion for further studies, where the write-up is not actually the abstract

Viewing graphs as matrices lets you play with them as if they're positive real numbers, and leads to some really fast (parallel) algorithms for classical problems. For reference: Algorithm Design Using Spectral Graph Theory

I ran computer simulations of a problem in classical dynamics (in applied maths) looking for solutions with certain properties, and then I used the intuition I gained from looking at them to prove something about how to make some of them have a particular property (and how to determine if it has that property from a symbolic representation of the solution) — and then I wrote it up in the opposite order because it makes a better story.

If you take a material that conventional band theory (with non-interacting electrons in a perfectly periodic crystal) would predict to be conducting and add either interactions alone or disorder alone (e.g., structural or chemical imperfections in the crystal), this drives the material towards insulating behavior (Mott insulators with interactions and Anderson insulators with disorder), but if you add both interactions and disorder you can realize various insulating, conducting, and glassy phases, and it's fun to study these phases and the phase transitions between them.
Tiny changes to tiny molecules cause tiny solid-state structural changes that cause less-tiny efficiency gains in tiny lab-scale solar cells.

Great answers here. Mine was; why (or how) do giant elliptical galaxies shine so brightly in X rays? In more detail; we know (and knew) that these galaxies contain a diffuse (density of atoms per cubic metre) gas which falls towards the centre of the galaxy and heats up, radiating X rays as it does. The question was, how else did it behave as it fell? Just allowing it to reach the middle would deposit unreasonable amounts of gas at the centre. At the time the theory was that it would condense out as stars but we don't see that. My supervisors idea was that some of the gas would fall into the central black hole powering it and thus heating the rest of the gas from beneath, causing it to convect. I worked through the modelling of this idea. Lots of thanks to my supervisor James Binney for everything!

I stuffed young rats into frosting cones and asked them how they felt. They were sad. Ph.D. (Pharmaceutical Sciences), Mercer University College of Pharmacy. Development and Evaluation of an Adolescent Chronic Restraint Stress (aCRS) Model of Depression in Adult Female Rats.
The development of science in the 18th century was delayed because those who had the best mathematics used the wrong physics, and those who had the right physics had the worst mathematics.

The space elevator is a concept for getting payloads into space without the need for excessive rocket fuel. The elevator stays up on its own because it reaches beyond geostationary. However, travel times are long. Therefore, … A rotating space elevator (RSE) is a looped string reaching into outer space. Unlike the classical geo-stationary space elevator concepts of Tsiolkovsky, Artsutanov, and Pearson, our RSE exhibits an internal rotation. Thanks to this, objects sliding along the RSE loop spontaneously oscillate between two turning points, one of which is close to the Earth whereas the other one is in outer space. The RSE concept thus solves a major problem in space elevator technology which is how to supply energy to the climbers moving along space elevator strings. The investigation of the classical and statistical mechanics of a floppy string interacting with objects sliding along it required development of subtle computational algorithms.

If I had to summarise my thesis in one sentence, it would be: “You can detect gravitational waves by analysing the motion of stars on the sky” In reality, my PhD research includes a few different projects in gravitational wave physics, related to theory and analysis of data, but my main project that I got hired to do is investigating whether one can detect gravitational waves using astrometric data from the Gaia mission.
There’s a family of joint distributions over finite sets of Bernoulli random variables that has properties analogous to the multivariate normal distribution, and it’s really interesting otherwise.

The way to balance the video game designer’s desire to tell a good story against the video game player’s desire to do whatever he or she wants to do, is through the role that the player plays in the story.

There’s no easy example of something that you can’t always do, but can still do most of the time. Even though someone else says there is. What I actually did: Someone suggested a definition of what it means to “mostly solve” a problem - but it turns out that you can “mostly solve” just about anything if you look at it the right way. I came up with a stricter definition, and showed that the usual known-unsolvable problems are also impossible to “mostly solve”. (I also did some other things, studying variants on the original definitions of “mostly solved” and investigating how complicated problems that fit my definition had to be, but the above is what I’d call the main result.) For reference: Asymptotic density and effective negligibility

“If you are going to replace a part of a system, make sure the replacement part fits.” Title: A systems architecture-based approach to assess candidate upgrades to complex systems The Compatibility evaluation Method (CAM), a new structured procedure for evaluating compatibility between mother or father systems and youngster subsystems, is proposed and placed on a number of instances when subsystems are now being changed in legacy methods. CAM is a screening procedure meant to be used by project managers who require to displace components of complex systems.

You can make (computer models of) balls packed in a (computer model of a) box flow by (computationally) pushing on them, you can measure the temperature of this fluid with a (computer model of a) sluggish thermometer, and the fluid flows in the same way as it would if it were (computationally) heated to that temperature but not (computationally) pushed on.

Using an off-resonance pulse, you can get the same information as you do in MRI imaging when you use long echo times to try to measure T2* relaxation times, but without all the signal loss (because we can use short echo times). There is this strange thing called “disinformation” which I discovered while investigating US operations in Chile. At the time, there was 1 mention of “disinformation” by a US Russian expert published in an obscure quartely. At the time, in a University library with 10 million books there were 2 on “psychological warfare”. There was no use or understanding whatever in the US media of “disinfomation” or what relation it might have to “psychological warfare”. Up to this point “disinformation” was a term used strictly within intelligence and military agencies but not by journalists or the public.
